document_title: Chronic glomerulonephritis: Causes, symptoms, diagnosis and prevention
subsection_content:
There is no specific treatment for chronic glomerulonephritis; treatment goals include:
Prevention of acute progression; Limit the progression of glomerular damage, maintain glomerular function; Homeostasis regulation; Treatment of complications; Treat the underlying disease; Change your diet appropriately and have a healthy lifestyle to slow down the progression of the disease.
The doctor will evaluate your health status and current kidney filtering function to come up with an appropriate treatment regimen. Furthermore, the doctor will also base on the patient's clinical symptoms to prescribe supportive medications.
Medications commonly used to relieve symptoms of chronic glomerulonephritis include:
Antihypertensive drugs; Anti-inflammatory drugs or antibiotics for people with chronic glomerulonephritis secondary to infection; Corticosteroids and immunosuppressants in some specific cases; Diuretics when there is edema; Treatment of anemia; Treatment is based on the cause (such as Diabetes, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus...); For end-stage patients with uncontrolled hyperkalemia or uncontrolled fluid overload, emergency dialysis or periodic dialysis may be required.
Patients also need to pay attention to the following things about the diet for patients with chronic enterococcal disease. This diet can also be applied to other cases of chronic kidney disease.
Limit salt, potassium, and phosphorus; Only consume a sufficient amount of protein, limit eating too much protein-rich foods; Limit eating foods with electrolytes
This nutritional regimen helps patients balance the levels of electrolytes, minerals and fluids in the body. Furthermore, it also limits the accumulation of waste in the patient's body.
